Mikhail Gorbachev hopes to visit the New York Stock Exchange, have lunch with bankers, open a Soviet exhibition and do some sightseeing during a visit to New York City next week, Soviet officials said. A1

Fujitsu of Japan must pay I.B.M. at least $833.3 million to settle a dispute over its copying of software necessary to build computers compatible with I.B.M.'s most powerful machines, two arbitrators ruled. A1

A British anti-terrorist law violates the European Convention on Human Rights, a Strasbourg court ruled. The law lets the police detain people suspected of ties with terrorists for up to a week before arraignment. A19
The Soviets and Afghan rebel leaders are preparing for high-level talks, possibly in Saudi Arabia within the week, Afghans said. It would be the first meeting at such a level between them. A14
Pressure on Peru's President to resign or call early elections is mounting as inflation runs at more than 2,000 percent a year and political violence rises. A10
Israel's Labor Party is expected today to approve by a close vote further negotiations with Likud over forming a national unity government. A11
Fear that a U.N. General Assembly meeting in Geneva would damage U.N. ties with its host country is troubling some diplomats. But they see the move as inevitable. A13
Gunman wounds the president of the major Sikh political party A8
Soviet Parliament opens session to reorganize the government A18

NATIONAL A20-28, B8-10 Democrats elected George Mitchell of Maine as Senate Majority Leader, seeking a strong party spokesman. Mr. Mitchell defeated two senior rivals, Daniel Inouye of Hawaii and J. Bennett Johnston of Louisiana. A1

Man in the news: George Mitchell was appointed to the Senate in 1980, and pundits counted him out of the next election. Consistency and competitiveness kept him in office and raised him to Senate leadership. A1
A nuclear reactor at a weapon plant in South Carolina can not be restarted until the spring or summer because new operating and safety programs have not been completed, the Energy Department said. A1
The Supreme Court made it harder for criminal defendants to challenge their convictions in cases in which the police have mishandled evidence that might have proved them innocent. A1
The judge in the Iran-contra case turned down motions by Oliver North to throw out two main charges against him, but the judge dismissed a related charge involving wire fraud. A21
President-elect Bush's eagerness to have his national security team in place has been tempered by his desire to shape a management team that will streamline the Pentagon, transition aides said. B8
A long list of pollution problems as diverse as urban smog, polluted beaches and global warming will confront the Bush administration. Mr. Bush will meet with environmental groups today. B10
A reduction in air fares to Florida will be offered in January, the major airlines announced. But the price increases that went into effect last week on other routes remain. A22

Insurance pay for Medicare patients who receive medically-assisted kidney dialysis at home is to be reduced, the Federal government has directed, contending that Congress never intended to provide this service. A20
The FDA approved test kits that detect antibodies to a rare cancer virus in blood. Nationwide testing of donated blood is expected to begin next month. A28

A ban on the hormones and drugs that stop milk production to avoid breast engorgement, which is sometimes painful in women who do not breast feed, was called for by a health group in a petition to the FDA. A26

Black and Jewish civil rights hands gathered in Altanta for a reunion to celebrate a coalition that has fostered broad social changes over the last 80 years. Current tensions were handled gingerly. A20
Weather threatens to delay secret shuttle mission A28

WASHINGTON TALK B10 REGIONAL B1-7, B28 A proposed construction agency for New York City schools is ''dead in its current form,'' the New York State Senate majority leader, Warren Anderson, said, effectively eliminating the chances for one this year. A1

News analysis: A commission on planning created 50 years ago to shape New York City's future has become narrowly focused, devoting as much energy to zoning and land use as to the city's overall course. B1
A Japanese man arrested in Jersey after three bombs were found in his car was convicted in a rare nonjury proceeding that left his goals and targets shrouded in mystery. B1

The New York City Police strategy of saturating neighborhoods with undercover narcotics officers is not a panacea for the city's drug problem, New York City Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward conceded. B3
A witness in the Myerson trial said that Bess Myerson screamed, cursed and described the Federal investigation of her as a ''witch hunt.'' B3
Pool moves up the social ladder B1
